{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's symptoms of difficulty urinating, trouble speaking, changes in vision, and facial pain suggest a neurological issue. The fact that leftward gaze results in only the ipsilateral eye gazing leftward indicates a problem with the cranial nerves, specifically the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI), which controls lateral eye movement. These symptoms, along with the relapsing-remitting course, are suggestive of multiple sclerosis (MS). The best initial test for MS is an MRI of the brain and spinal cord, which can show the characteristic plaques of demyelination. While the patient's history of domestic abuse is concerning and should be addressed, it is not the cause of her neurological symptoms.", "answer_choice": "B. Head MRI"}
